header.title: Table of Questions (Part 5)
authors: Likely Rabbi Yehuda Ashlag or Rabbi Baruch Ashlag (from 'Ohr Pnimi')

central_thesis: This section serves as a technical glossary for a complex Kabbalistic system, providing precise definitions for key terms related to the emanation, descent, and rectification of spiritual lights (Orot) and vessels (Kelim) within the spiritual cosmos (Olamot) and their configurations (Partzufim). The underlying philosophy posits a structured, dynamic universe where divine light interacts with spiritual vessels through specific mechanisms, which these definitions are intended to elucidate.

structure_content.chapter_title: Part Five: Table of Questions for the Meaning of the Words
structure_content.summary: This section comprises 42 numbered questions, each followed by a detailed, technical answer defining a specific Kabbalistic term. The definitions explain the nature, function, and interrelationships of concepts such as various types of spiritual light (Ohr), spiritual vessels (Kelim), screens (Masach), phases of spiritual extension (Hitpashtut) and withdrawal (Histalkut), and different aspects of spiritual perception and reception (Panim, Achor). It establishes the precise terminology necessary for understanding the mechanics of the spiritual world within the system being described.

key_concepts.definition: The measure of light (Komat Ohr) extending on a spiritual screen (Masach) with the coarseness (Aviut) of the first spiritual level (Behina Aleph), characterized by not extending any light of higher intellect (Behinat GAR).
The part of the residue (Reshimo) of direct light (Ohr Yashar) contained within a Partzuf, distinguishing it from the residue of returning light (Ohr Hozer) which is called 'Inferior Ohr'.
The light (Ohr) extended into a spiritual configuration (Partzuf) as a result of a direct spiritual impact (Zivug de Hakaa).

The spiritual impressions (Reshimot) left behind by the departing lights (Orot) after their initial extension (Hitpashtut Aleph), representing the inherent lights existing in the Partzuf from its initial formation.
A spiritual aspect (Behina) within a vessel (Kli) that is currently inactive or not functioning, either for bestowing light or receiving it. Also referred to as Achoraim.
A measure of spiritual stature (Koma) primarily derived from the coarseness (Aviut) of the first spiritual level (Behina Aleph), known as HaVaYaH de Alephin.

A term for the lowest Sefira, Malchut, signifying its comprehensive nature as the root (Shoresh) of all twenty-two letters (Otiot) of creation, implying it contains the entire alphabet from Aleph to Tav.

A state where there is a void or absence of light (Ohr) across two spiritual levels, specifically between the vessel of loving-kindness (Kli de Hesed) and the vessel of crown (Kli de Keter), indicating that the vessels of wisdom (Hochma) and understanding (Bina) are empty of light, thereby preventing the illumination of higher intellect (He'arat GAR) in the Partzuf.

The transmission of lights (Orot) between Sefirot through the purification (Hizdakchut) of the screen (Masach). This process involves a sequential passage of light from Keter to Hochma, then Bina, etc., as the Aviut purifies. This is distinct from 'Giving of Orot' as a general term.
The act of one Sefira receiving from or giving to another, implying a direct interaction or 'looking at each other' between them.

The 'First Hey' of the divine name HaVaYaH refers to the general withdrawal (Histalkut) of light during the first extension (Hitpashtut Aleph), while the 'Last Hey de HaVaYaH' refers to the general withdrawal of light during the second extension (Hitpashtut Bet).
The measure of the stature (Koma) of the lowest spiritual level (Behinat Malchut), referred to as HaVaYaH in its filling (milui) of Heyin.

The state where a Partzuf possesses a rectified spiritual screen (Masach) with a suitable measure of coarseness (Aviut) for a spiritual impact (Zivug) to extend the supernal light (Ohr Elyon), making the Partzuf ready to receive that light.

A situation where a spiritual vessel (Kli de Panim) is cancelled, yet continues to receive light through its posterior aspect (Achoraim). For example, after the coarseness of Behina Dalet is cancelled, the Kli receives illumination from Behina Gimel through what is now its Achoraim (Behina Gimel acting as Achor relative to the prior Behina Dalet).
The first withdrawal (Histalkut) of lights (Orot) back to the emanator (Maatzil), which occurred in the spiritual worlds (Olamot), specifically in Partzuf Keter de AK (Adam Kadmon).
The second withdrawal (Histalkut) that occurred in the spiritual worlds (Olamot), specifically in Partzuf Hochma de AK (Adam Kadmon), also known as Partzuf AB de AK.

Occurs when the 'Av' (coarser) part of a vessel (Kli), initially designated as Panim (front) for receiving the main light, becomes inoperative, and the less 'Av' (finer) part, previously Achor (back), becomes the receiver of a lower measure of light. This reorients the vessel's receptivity from its original 'front' to its 'back'.

The process where two lights (Orot) from two distinct spiritual levels (Behinot) incorporate and unite, receiving illumination (He'arah) from each other as if they were one Behina. This can occur without vessels, in two vessels, or in one vessel, depending on the stage of emanation.

The descent of light (Ohr) from above downward into spiritual vessels (Kelim), signifying the formation of the spiritual body (Guf). This term specifically refers to the Guf of Partzuf Keter de AK, which is the initial Guf in the Olamot.
Refers to the Guf of Partzuf Hochma de AK (Adam Kadmon), also known as Partzuf AB de AK. There is also a second Behina of Hitpashtut Bet, which is Partzuf Bina de AK, called Partzuf SAG de AK.
The measure of coarseness (Aviut) associated with the spiritual levels of Behina Gimel and Behina Bet.

The sequential process by which lights (Orot) entered the vessels (Kelim) of Hitpashtut Bet, moving from Keter down to Malchut. This occurred through a mechanism of 'Matei ve Lo Matei', where light initially extended (Matei) then withdrew (Lo Matei) from a higher Sefira, allowing it to enter the next lower Sefira.

Yod (י) implies the points (Nekudim) of Hitpashtut Aleph, representing lights from Hochma downwards. Vav (ו) implies the points (Nekudim) of Hitpashtut Bet, also from Hochma downwards. The Keter lights of both Hitpashtut Aleph and Bet are not insinuated within the four letters of HaVaYaH.

In Hitpashtut Bet, the supernal light (Ohr Keter) did not return to its original place but remained in the 'Peh' (mouth). Consequently, each Sefira descended, meaning Ohr Hochma clothed in Kli de Keter, Ohr Bina in Kli de Hochma, and so forth, with Keter effectively descending to the degree of Hochma, and Hochma to Bina, etc.

The mutual reception of illumination (He'arah) between the male (Zachar) and female (Nekeva) aspects of spiritual entities. This occurs in three forms: without vessels (ascending to Malchut de Rosh), in two vessels (in AB), or in one vessel (in SAG).
The Crown (Keter) of the Roots, referring to Keter de Rosh, as all Ten Sefirot of the Head (Rosh) are considered the roots (Shorashim) for the Ten Sefirot of the Body (Guf).
The Crown (Keter) light of the Ten Sefirot of the spiritual body (Guf), signifying Keter as an aspect of the 'branches' (Anafim) of the system.
A spiritual mechanism where 'Matei' denotes the extension (Hitpashtut) of the Supernal Light (Ohr Elyon) to a Sefira, and 'Lo Matei' denotes the withdrawal (Histalkut) of that light from the Sefira.

The measure of coarseness (Aviut) present in the spiritual screen (Masach) within a vessel (Kli) that enables the spiritual impact (Zivug Elyon) to occur, thereby causing the Kli to be 'filled' with light (Ohr).
The lowest Sefira, Malchut, when located in the Head (Rosh), is considered the 'Malchut of the Roots', as all Ten Sefirot of the Rosh are fundamentally considered roots (Shorashim).

The process of administering lights (Orot) from one Sefira to another through the purification (Hizdakchut) of the screen (Masach). This involves a sequential transmission of Orot from Keter down to Malchut as the Aviut purifies. Distinct from 'Only He'arot'.

A state signifying that a specific light (Ohr) has departed from a spiritual configuration (Partzuf) and will not return to it, or refers to a spiritual impression (Reshimo) whose corresponding light will permanently not return to the Partzuf.

The 'Branches of the Mouth', referring to the Ten Sefirot of the spiritual body (Guf). These Sefirot are considered an expansion (Hitpashtut) of Malchut de Rosh (the 'Peh'), which extends from the Rosh downward to form the Guf.
The designated location or aspect within a spiritual vessel (Kli) that is prepared or suitable for either bestowing spiritual light or receiving it.

Within a vessel (Kli), if it dispenses complete spiritual light (GAR), that aspect is its Panim; the aspect dispensing lesser light (VAK) is its Achor. Conversely, if the Kli primarily dispenses VAK, then the VAK-dispensing aspect is its Panim, and the GAR-dispensing aspect is its Achor.
In the spiritual screen (Masach), the thickest (most Av) spiritual level (Behina) constitutes its Panim (front), while the less Av (thinner) Behina represents its Achor (back).

A condition where the spiritual screen (Masach) purifies itself of its coarseness (Aviut), causing the spiritual impact (Zivug) to cease, the light (Ohr) to depart from the vessel (Kli), and the 'letters' (Otiot, which are the Kelim) to be considered without 'filling' because the Aviut, which is the cause of the filling, has been purified.

Refers to the light of loving-kindness (Ohr Hesed) within the vessel of understanding (Kli de Bina), which is described as 'Thin and Frail Ohr'. It originates from a spiritual impact (Zivug) with Behina Aleph, lacking the illumination of higher intellect (He'arat GAR). It 'needs its mother' (Bina) until it receives He'arat Hochma to attain its full stature (Gadlut) and become independent.

The 'Sight of the Eyes', referring to the Supernal Light (Ohr Elyon) that extends for a spiritual impact (Zivug de Hakaa). This concept is derived from the verse 'And God saw the light, that it was good,' and implies the light of wisdom (Ohr Hochma), which is the essence (Atzmut) of the direct light (Ohr Yashar) emanating from the Infinite (Ein Sof).

The spiritual impression (Reshimo) whose corresponding light (Ohr) will not return to the Partzuf. Specifically, the Ohr Keter that remains concealed under Malchut of the Rosh and does not descend to the Guf in Hitpashtut Bet, but its Reshimo operates in Kli de Keter. This remaining Ohr Keter acts as a permanent root (Shoresh) from which illumination shines to its Reshimo.
Refers to the Ten Sefirot of the Head (Rosh), which are considered the roots (Shorashim) of the Ten Sefirot of the spiritual body (Guf).
Refers to the Supernal Roots, which are the Ten Sefirot of the Head (Rosh).

practical_system.description: While not a practical manual itself, this text provides the foundational conceptual framework for a highly detailed Kabbalistic practical system centered on spiritual rectification (Tikkun). The definitions explicate the inner workings of the spiritual universe and the human soul, guiding the practitioner in understanding the mechanisms of spiritual light (Ohr), vessel (Kli), and screen (Masach). These concepts are implicitly tied to practices aimed at purifying one's desires (Aviut), building rectified vessels (Kelim), and achieving union with the divine light through specific intentions (Kavanot) and meditative practices. Understanding these terms is crucial for performing effective 'Zivugim' (spiritual impacts) and progressing through the stages of spiritual ascent (Histalkut) and descent (Hitpashtut) towards a state of 'Preparation to Receive' higher Orot.
tools: Conceptual frameworks (Ohr, Kli, Masach, Partzufim, Sefirot, Aviut, Reshimot)

relevant_quotes.text: The Komat Ohr extending on a Masach of Aviut de Behina Aleph is called 'A Thin and Frail Ohr', as it does not extend anything of Behinat GAR.
A Behina that does not operate in the Kli, whether for bestowal or for reception, is called Achor, or Achoraim.

When there is a corrected Masach in the Partzuf at a suitable measure of Aviut fit for a Zivug and to extend the Ohr Elyon, the Partzuf is then considered to have a 'Preparation to Receive' the Ohr Elyon.

The more Av in the wall of the Kli is called Panim because the Zivug Elyon is made on it and the Ohr extends through it, but the part that is not so Av, is called Achor since it does not operate in the Kli. If the Ohr Pnimi departs from the Kli and the Kli receives Ohr from a low Koma, and this Koma is suitable to the measure of the Aviut in this Kli, that Ohr will be received in the part that is not so Av, suitable for that Koma. It turns out that it now turned its Panim downward, the Av part in the Kli has been cancelled and its Achoraim are upward, as the Achor part of the Kli has now become the receiver of the Ohr.
Matei indicates the Hitpashtut Ohr Elyon to the Sefira; Lo Matei indicates Histalkut of the Ohr from the Sefira.

critical_analysis.relevance: This glossary is exceptionally relevant for deep engagement with Lurianic Kabbalah, particularly as interpreted by the Ashlag school. It provides the essential, precise terminology required to navigate the complex cosmological and psycho-spiritual dynamics of the system. Without a clear understanding of these definitions, the intricacies of spiritual emanation, purification, and rectification (Tikkun) remain obscure. Its technical precision enables a systematic, almost scientific, approach to understanding esoteric processes, contrasting with more generalized or allegorical interpretations of Kabbalah.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The target audience for this text is advanced students and dedicated practitioners of Lurianic Kabbalah, particularly those studying 'Talmud Eser Sefirot' and its commentaries like 'Ohr Pnimi'. It presupposes a foundational understanding of basic Kabbalistic concepts and is intended to refine and deepen that understanding. It is also invaluable for academic researchers specializing in Jewish mysticism who require a precise lexicon for their studies.
